'''Gualdo Tadino''', (Latin: ''Tadinum'') an ancient town of [[Italy]], in the [[province of Perugia]] in northeastern [[Umbria]], on the lower flanks of [[Monte Penna|Mt. Penna]], a mountain of the Apennines. It is 47&nbsp;km  NE of [[Perugia]] and 30&nbsp;km SE of [[Gubbio]].
==History==
{{Expand section|date=June 2008}}
Gualdo has a long history and was originally an [[Umbrians|Umbrian]] village known as '''Tarsina'''. Conquered by the [[ancient Roman|Romans]] in 266 BC and re-christened '''Tadinum''', it was a station on the [[Via Flaminia]]. In 217 BC it was destroyed by [[Hannibal]]'s troops. A similar defeat was inflicted on it in 47 BC by [[Julius Caesar]] and in 410 AD by [[Alaric I|Alaric]]'s [[Visigoths]].
In 552, the [[Byzantine Empire|Byzantine]] general [[Narses]] briefly restored Italy to the empire by defeating the [[Ostrogoths|Ostrogoth]] king [[Baduila]] in what is now known as the [[Battle of Taginae]], the exact site of which is not known, but thought by most scholars to be a few kilometers from the town, in the plain to the west at a place called Taino. This suspicion may have received confirmation in 2004.
The ancient city survived that war, only to be destroyed in a later war at the instigation of the [[Holy Roman Emperor]] [[Otto III]] in 966. It was later rebuilt, only to be destroyed a second time by fire in 1237. Finally, the Emperor [[Frederick II, Holy Roman Emperor|Frederick II]] ordered the city rebuilt for a third time in 1239, and it is this incarnation which survives today.
Gualdo Tadino sister cities are: [[West Pittston]], PA (USA) and Audun Le Tiche, France
==Main sights==
*[[Rocca Flea]], a 12th-century castle which is now the main monument of the town.
*[[San Francesco, Gualdo Tadino|San Francesco]] (13th century), housing frescoes by [[Matteo da Gualdo]].
*Church of ''Santa Chiara'' (13th century).
*''Palazzo del Podest��''.
*''Torre Civica'' (Town Tower).
*[[Gualdo Tadino Cathedral]] (Church of St. Benedict), with an external fountain attributed to [[Antonio da Sangallo the Elder]] (16th century).
*Civic Gallery, with works by Matteo da Gualdo and others.
==Economy==
[[Image:Piatto ceramica umbra.jpg|thumb|left|180px|<center>Traditional umbrian ceramic plate</center>]]
The city was famous in the Middle Ages for the manufacture of [[ceramic]] ware; in the late 20th century, the ceramic industry was revived, and Gualdo is now an important center for the manufacture of industrial ceramics and bathroom fittings.
{{-}}
==Transportation==
{{Expand section|date=June 2008}}
Gualdo Tadino has a railway station on the line from [[Ancona]] to [[Foligno]], with some trains continuing through to Rome. The journey time to Ancona is typically one hour and 45 minutes, and to Foligno 40 minutes.
